bio: My love for programming started when I was a kid writing games in QuickBasic on Intel 3/486 machines. This hobby began to transition into a career when I started working professionally in 2013 on a Python Django website. Since then I have had the privilege of working on many projects, giving me the opportunity to learn a wide range of technologies and tools. I am always excited to grow deeper in my understanding or widen my knowledge by learning something new.

boxes.title: Albums
boxes.paragraph: I can be heard on these albums

boxes.title: Skills
boxes.paragraph: I have particular and recent experience with the following technologies
items: JavaScript / TypeScript / JQuery / React / AngularJS / Angular

boxes.title: Tools
boxes.paragraph: I use these tools to get things done. I think you can learn a lot about a developer from their [dotfiles]()
items: Spectacle - To move windows with my keyboard
JetBrains PhpStorm - Because IDEs are great sometimes
tmux/tmuxilator - here's my config !! put on github !!

boxes.title: Education
boxes.paragraph: I think this is a good point to be upfront that I don't have a CS degree. While I don't wish to undervalue such degrees and may pursue such a degree at some point, in my experience the day-to-day skills required for what I do are not imparted by such degrees and esoteric knowledge can be studied and learned in context much more easily than in the more abstract academic setting. I am routinely baffled by the things that people DON'T learn in such programs. Most importantly, knowledge in this industry is easily available online and in excellent books and reading a text is a lot more meaningful when you're actually doing real work. If you disagree, no problem. You can probably grab another cup of coffee and move on to another prospect.

boxes.title: Books
boxes.paragraph: I highly recommend these books for the wisdom or knowledge they impart or for the thoughts they provoke. These are all available as audiobooks because that's how I roll for anything non-technical.

items.title: The Coddling of the American Mind
